content.text:
The following data refer to a section of base line measured by a tape hung in catenary.<image 1>Length of tape between 0 and 30 m graduations when horizontal at 20°C and under 5 kg tension is 29.9988 m; cross-sectional area of tape = 2.68 $mm^{2}^$; tension used in the field = 10 kg; temperature coefficient of expansion of tape = $11.16 * 10^{-6}$ per °C; elastic modulus for material of tape = $20.4 * 10^{4} N/mm^{2}$; weight of tape per metre length = 0.02 kg; mean radius of the Earth = $6.4*10^{6}$ m.Calculate the corrected length of this section of the line.

A. 150.507 m
B. 152.507 m
C. 153.507 m
D. 151.507 m

To calculate the corrected length of the section of the line, we need to consider the effects of temperature, tension, and the curvature of the Earth on the measured length. The formula to calculate the corrected length is:

\[ L_{\text{correcteded}} = L_{\text{measured}} + \Delta L_{\text{temperature}} + \Delta L_{\text{tension}} + \Delta L_{\text{curvature}} \]

where:
- \( L_{\text{measured}} \) is the measured length ( (30.034 m)
- \( \Delta L_{\text{temperature}} \) is the change in length due to temperature
- \( \Delta L_{\text{tension}} \) is the change in length due to tension
- \( \Delta L_{\text{curvature}} \) is the change in length due to the curvature of the Earth

### Step 1: Calculate \( \Delta L_{\text{temperature}} \)

The change in length due to temperature can be calculated using the formula:

\[ \Delta L_{\text{temperature}} = L_{\text{measured}} \times \alpha \times \Delta T \]

where:
- \( \alpha \) is the temperature coefficient of expansion of the tape ( \(11.16 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{per} \, ^{\circ} \text{C}\)
- \( \Delta T \) is the change in temperature from the reference temperature ( (20°C to 25.2°C)

\[ \Delta T = 25.2°C - 20°C = 5.2°C \]

\[ \Delta L_{\text{temperature}} = 30.034 \, \text{m} \times 11.16 \times 10^{-6} \, \text{per} \, ^{\circ} \text{C} \times 5.2°C \]

\[ \Delta L_{\text{temperature}} = 30.034 \, \text{m} \times 11.16 \times 10^{-6} \times 5.2 \]

\[ \Delta L_{\text{temperature}} = 1.76 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m} \]

### Step 2: Calculate \( \Delta L_{\text{tension}} \)

The change in length due to tension can be calculated using the formula:

\[ \Delta L_{\text{tension}} = \frac{L_{\text{measured}} \times \Delta T_{\text{tension}}}{E \times A} \]

where:
- \( \Delta T_{\text{tension}} \) is the change in tension from the reference tension ( (5 kg to 10 kg)
- \( E \) is the elastic modulus of the tape \( 20.4 \times 10^{4} \, \text{N/mm}^2 \)
- \( A \) is the cross-sectional area of the tape \( 2.68 \, \text{mm}^2 \)

\[ \Delta T_{\text{tension}} = 10 \, \text{kg} - 5 \, \text{kg} = 5 \, \text{kg} \]

\[ \Delta L_{\text{tension}} = \frac{30.034 \, \text{m} \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \times 5 \
